msgSnippet: Paul, It is not a package problem as I am able to execute it using the textui.TestRunner. The problem appears when I try to cast a particular object as another

Paul,

        It is not a package problem as I am able to execute it using=
 the textui.TestRunner. The problem appears when I try to cast a particular=
 object as another Class. This casting goes through fine with the textui fl=
avour, but gives a problem if I use any other flavour TestRunner. It appear=
s that there are 2 class loaders at work here and hence the problem. If no =
one has come across this earlier or no one knows a possible resolution I mi=
ght have to go through the TestRunner code - something which I don't want t=
o do :-)

thanks,
Rama



-------Original Message-------


From: Paul Micha=
li 
To: junit@egroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Classspath for ClassLoader

=
G Ramasubramani wrote: 
However, in case I invoke it throught the GUI,
  
 =
    >java junit.swingui.TestRunner A
  
     then an error is thrown. It ap=
pears to be a ClassLoader issue as the error thrown is a
 ClassCastExceptio=
n. 

I'm just (re)learning Java and learning JUnit, so take this with a gra=
in of salt... 
I had a similar problem, where I could not run my class from=
 the GUI. I was 
getting an error from the class loader (not sure if it is =
the same). Someone on 
this list indicated that, because I was using a "pac=
kage" I had to include the 
package in the invocation. So I had to do somet=
hing like: 
java junit.swingui.TestRunner mypackagename.A 
You may want to =
try this, if it applies and please let us know how it works. 
Otherwise, ma=
ybe someone more experienced can give you a definitive 
answer instead of a=
 feeble guess :^)
